Issues.Title: Refactoring AutomationId at the accessible object classes #6603
Issues.Body:
Fixes #6603
This PR finishes https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/6641 (adds unit tests)

## Proposed changes

- The AutomationId property is moved to the AccessibleObject base class
- This property returns null at AccessibleObject
- It is returned at the GetPropertyValue method of AccessibleObject for the case AutomationIdPropertyId
- The current implementations in the 4 classes derived from AO are kept the same way, but they are marked as overrides
- Returning of the Owner.Name is moved to the ControlAccessibleObjectObject class to make it universal for all its descendants
- All duplicate code with the same logic is cleaned out in the derived classes
- Initial discussion on this topic is here: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/6429#issuecomment-1009286397

Unit tests:

1) AccessibleObject - AccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_ReturnsNull (two unit tests combined)
2) DataGridViewCellAccessibleObject - DataGridViewCellAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_AutomationId_ReturnsExpected (new)
3) ListViewItemBaseAccessibleObject - ListViewItemBaseAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_AutomationId_ReturnsExpected (new)
4) ListViewSubItemAccessibleObject - ListViewSubItemAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_returns_correct_values (existing)
5) ControlAccessibleObject - ControlAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_AutomationId_ReturnsExpected (new)
6) ButtonBaseAccessibleObject - ButtonBaseAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_AutomationId_ReturnsExpected (new)
7) CheckBoxAccessibleObject - CheckBoxAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (existing)
8) GroupBoxAccessibleObject - GroupBoxAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_AutomationId_ReturnsExpected (new)
9) LabelAccessibleObject - LabelAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (two unit tests combined)
10) ListViewAccessibleObject - ListViewAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_returns_correct_values (existing)
11) PanelAccessibleObject - PanelAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (existing)
12) PictureBoxAccessibleObject - PictureBoxAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (existing)
13) RadioButtonAccessibleObject - RadioButtonAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (existing)
14) ScrollBarAccessibleObject - ScrollBarAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (existing)
15) SplitterAccessibleObject - SplitterAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (existing)
16) TabControlAccessibleObject - TabControlAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (two unit tests combined)
17) TabPageAccessibleObject - TabPageAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (two unit tests combined)
18) TrackBarAccessibleObject - TrackBarAccessibilityObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected (two unit tests combined)

	Combined existed NamePropertyId tests and new AutomationIdPropertyId tests:
	{
		TrackBarAccessibilityObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected
		TabPageAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected
		TabControlAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected
		LabelAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected
	}
	just like existing:
	{
		CheckBoxAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected
		PanelAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected
		PictureBoxAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_Invoke_ReturnsExpected
                ListViewSubItemAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_returns_correct_values
		ListViewAccessibleObject_GetPropertyValue_returns_correct_values
	}
<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Tests based on the old implementation of AutomationId could become obsolete

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Unit tests
- CTI testing

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

Microsoft Windows [Version 120.2212.4170.0]
.NET Core SDK: 7.0.100-preview.3.22179.4


<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->

Issues.Title: Restore ToolboxSnapDragDropEventArgs implementation
Issues.Body:
Resolves #6919

 `ToolboxSnapDragDropEventArgs` is necessary to facilitate the "general purpose designer" experience as shown in [#6919](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/6919#issuecomment-1121000602).

## Proposed changes

- Restore `ToolboxSnapDragDropEventArgs` implementation. The type was ported in #122, but had no actual use until #4860, when `ToolboxItemSnapLineBehavior` was ported for .NET 6 Preview5. It looks like a genuine oversight, given the size of #4860.
- Backport a part of the UI integration framework we added in .NET 7. This comes under TELL mode.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Without the implemented `ToolboxSnapDragDropEventArgs` it is not possible to provide the "general designer" experience, such as drag-and-drop a control or component from a toolbox.


## Regression? 

- Yes, from .NET Framework

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/168703595-68e5c235-fdad-4b8e-afbc-87debe96b057.png)


### After

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/168703297-4b7d345c-5e7e-402d-bb2f-d86d7f4e2766.png)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manually using the provided sample in #6919: [DesignerSample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/8651342/DesignerSample.zip)
- Added an integration test
- I have also reviewed another instances of NIE throughout the codebase, and there doesn't appear to be more issues of this kind. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/168704668-8d92362f-8cbe-46f6-a98b-94be7b2efe8b.png)
    * `ComponentDesigner` is largely implemented, and `InitializeExistingComponent` is expected to be implemented by developers of a "general purpose designer". 
    * We don't expect to provide implementations for `ComponentDocumentDesigner` unless there is a strong business justification. 
    * The same applies to `AxImporter`.
    * [`BindingContext.CollectionChanged` event](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.bindingcontext.collectionchanged#remarks) is obsoleted in .NET Framework

Issues.Title: [dotnet-sdk-7.0.100-preview.5.22267.11] Some controls are sometimes not displayed due to DPI settings and monitor
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

dotnet-sdk-7.0.100-preview.5.22267.11

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

**Verify Scenarios:**
1). Windows10 RS5 x64+dotnet-sdk-7.0.100-preview.5.22267.11: Fail
2). Windows10 RS5 x64+dotnet-sdk-5.0.214-win-x64: Pass
3). Windows10 RS5 x64+dotnet-sdk-7.0.100-preview.5.22263.22: Pass

### Issue description

**Application Name**:  AutoVersionsDB
**OS**: Windows 10 RS5
**CPU**: X64
**.NET Build Number**: dotnet-sdk-7.0.100-preview.5.22267.11
**Github Link**: https://github.com/modi-w/AutoVersionsDB

**App Source code or App Checking at**: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1543198/
**Github Link**: https://github.com/modi-w/AutoVersionsDB

### Steps to reproduce

**Minimal Repro steps:**
**The machine only has 7.0 installed. And DOTNET_ROLL_FORWARD_ON_NO_CANDIDATE_FX=2 is set.**
See attachment for source code.
[WinFormsApp3.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/8740651/WinFormsApp3.zip)

1. Create a Winform project, source code is 5.0
2. Create User Control
3. Add a panel to user control
4. Add labels to panel
5. Add user control to mainform
6. When we run our sample app with 5.0, labels are ok
![5 0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83067197/169543012-6510d339-8d16-4869-8761-52847f3703af.png)
7. when we run against 7, one label is partially shown, other one doesn't show.
![7 0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83067197/169543187-f369494d-3fee-4a5c-8ec7-ef241613a82a.png)

**Findings:**
When we add Application.SetHighDpiMode(HighDpiMode.SystemAware) to program.cs the Process Log button show part, maybe it is related to DPI.

**Repro steps on App**:
**The machine only has 7.0 installed. And DOTNET_ROLL_FORWARD_ON_NO_CANDIDATE_FX=2 is set.**

1. Install Localdb.
2. Copy [AutoVersionsDB] into your own machine.
3. Launch application from "AutoVersionsDB\AutoVersionsDB.WinApp.exe".
4. Click “New Project” button.
5. Type “test” in Id.
6. Type “test” in Description.
7. Type “(localdb)\mssqllocaldb” in Server.
8. Type “500” in Timeout.
9. Type “master” in DB Name.
10. Type your local folder path for DB Backup.
11. Type your local folder path for Scripts.
12. Type your local folder path for Deploy Artifact.
13. Click “Save” button.
14. Click “Process Log” button.

**Expected Result:** 
Click successfully.

**Actual Result:**
Can't find the button, it should be displayed on the right side.

@dotnet-actwx-bot @dotnet/compat

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] An onscreen element must not have a null BoundingRectangle property for PrintPreviewToolStrip Zoom button
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 7.0.100-preview.5.22267.11

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

This is a regression issue. .NET 7.0.100-preview.4.22252.9 and Net 6.0 not repro this issue

### Issue description

[Accessibility] An onscreen element must not have a null BoundingRectangle property for PrintPreviewToolStrip Zoom button

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open the attached project, build and run it 
[WinFormsApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/8738010/WinFormsApp1.zip)
2. Launch AccessibilityInsights
3. Click button1, and then in PrintPreview dialog
4. Focus on tool bar PrintPreviewToolStrip zoom button
5. Observe the result using AccessibilityInsights

Actual behavior:
AccessibilityInsights detected an error: An onscreen element must not have a null BoundingRectangle property
![Result](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96758262/169495047-f0ff79d1-e6c5-4f40-9643-3f85b0fe2a1e.PNG)

Expected behavior:
AccessibilityInsights should not detect this error.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] An onscreen element must not have a null BoundingRectangle property for PrintPreviewToolStrip Zoom button" (#7199)

Issues.Title: Second DataGridView with CalendarColumn does not display data in the cells
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Second-DataGridView-with-CalendarColumn-/10043008)._

---
[severity:It's more difficult to complete my work]
Using the CalendarColumn from the "How to: Host Controls in Windows Forms DataGridView Cells" documentation example, I have modified the program to create a DataTable to use as a source for the datagridview.
I use AutogenerateColumns=true and the ColumnAdded event to replace the textboxcolumn with the CalendarColumn. 
This works correctly for this first DataGridView.
I then duplicated the code to create a second DataGridView and second DataTable.
This second grid also uses AutoGenerateColumns and the ColumnAdded event to replace the textboxcolumn with the CalendarColumn. 
However, this second grid does not display values in the columns even though the column contains the CalendarColumn as can be show by editting a grid cell.
BUT, if I reverse the creation of the grids, by creating the second grid first, and the first grid second, then the second grid contains data but the first grid does not. To me this verifies that the code is correct. (ie. reverse lines 226 and 227, Build_grid_1() and Build_Grid_2() )
What is wrong, am I missing something?
PS. I am developing an application that needs to use a custom column in two grids displayed on the same form.
This is my test case. 
I will upload my test program.

Issues.Title: ListBox items' accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 7.0 Preview 4 

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

`ListBox` items' accessible objects are left in memory after the `ListBox` control instance with its items was inspected with accessibility tool (like Accessibility Insights or Inspect) and the form with `ListBox` is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened. Same applies for case when `ListBox` item is removed from `ListBox`.

Memory snapshot in VS:
![Screenshot 2022-05-18 174214](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/169345773-46837247-3587-4c4a-9c19-713cc48566a8.png)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the `ListBox` control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Press the second button to open the child form with `ListBox`.
3. Start the Accessibility Insights tools.
4. Run automated checks for the `ListBox` control using AI.
5. Close the child form.
6. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
7. DON'T close the AI tool.
8. Look for `ListBoxItemAccessibleObject` accessible objects left in memory (using WinDbg, or dotMemory, or another suitable tool).

Sample app: [ListBoxSample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/8731986/ListBoxSample.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ListBox items' accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#7197)

Issues.Title: TreeNode accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 7.0 Preview 4 (at least .NET 7.0 Preview 3, where `TreeNodeAccessibleObject` was introduced)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No (there was no `TreeNodeAccessibleObject`)

### Issue description

`TreeNode` accessible objects are left in memory after the `TreeView` control instance with its nodes was inspected with accessibility tool (like Accessibility Insights or Inspect) and the form with `TreeView` is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened. Same applies for case when `TreeNode` is removed from `TreeView`.

Memory snapshot in VS:
![Screenshot 2022-05-19 173414](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102954094/169343473-0b5da5d4-f12c-4e6f-abd2-503d24cd1071.png)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the `TreeView` control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Press the second button to open the child form with `TreeView`.
3. Start the Accessibility Insights tools.
4. Run automated checks for the `TreeView` control using AI.
5. Close the child form.
6. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
7. DON'T close the AI tool.
8. Look for `TreeNodeAccessibleObject` objects left in memory (using WinDbg, or dotMemory, or another suitable tool).

Sample app: [TreeViewSample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/8731946/TreeViewSample.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TreeNode accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#7196)

Issues.Title: VB fix title `MsgBox` and `InputBox` APIs
Issues.Body: Fixes #3161 ## Proposed changes - Fix the regression of `MsgBox` and `InputBox` APIs specifying no title and getting `Microsoft.VisualBasic.Core` (or other assembly name based on inlining) as their title instead of the calling assembly ## Customer Impact - Fixes a regression ## Regression? - No ## Risk - N/A ## Screenshots ### Before ### After ## Test methodology - I modified one of the projects in the solution to test it, I just removed the title parameter and gave it appropriate command-line arguments. Project name is in images above - I also tested it with the product property set in the project file, and it worked ## Accessibility testing Not sure if I need to run this, please advise ## Test environment(s) 200% scaling English ``` .NET SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 7.0.100-preview.3.22154.3 Commit: 5fe093bc35 Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.19044 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: \winforms\.dotnet\sdk\7.0.100-preview.3.22154.3\ global.json file: Not found Host: Version: 7.0.0-preview.5.22267.11 Architecture: x64 Commit: 5b1fd50332 .NET SDKs installed: 7.0.100-preview.3.22154.3 [\winforms\.dotnet\sdk] .NET runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 7.0.0-preview.3.22152.6 [\winforms\.dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 7.0.0-preview.3.22151.6 [\winforms\.dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 7.0.0-preview.5.22267.11 [\winforms\.dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 7.0.0-preview.3.22128.8 [\winforms\.dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] Download .NET: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download Learn about .NET Runtimes and SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet/runtimes-sdk-info ``` ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/7194)

Issues.Title: Fix TreeView overflow exception
Issues.Body:
Fixing an overflow exception in `TreeView` control in 32 bit process due to incorrect cast from `uint -> IntPtr`.

Fixes #7098 


## Proposed changes

- Cast return value (`nint`) of `GetMessagePos()` in the `TreeView `control to `int` before casting it to `IntPtr`


<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Customer should be able to use `TreeView `control in a 32-bit process.

## Regression? 

- Regressed from .NET 3.1

## Risk

- Low. Similar change is in .NET 7.0 since Preview 1

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->
